awd_titl_txt: Liquid Jet Atomization at Supercritical Pressure
awd_abstract_narration:
New technologies such as advanced gas-turbine engines and other advanced engines involve injection of liquids at higher pressures, which can reach levels that are hundreds of times greater than atmospheric pressure. There is a demand for new predictive capabilities to describe the sizes, shapes, and locations of small droplets breaking from the surface during the liquid-stream breakup (atomization) process. This project seeks an explanation of the physical mechanisms and to control of the breakup process and of the resulting spray.  Graduate and undergraduate students will conduct the project. Topical development will allow strengthening of various graduate courses in the topic of fluid dynamics and a future third edition of a textbook. Through existing UCI minority support programs, the Principal Investigator and his graduate students can support project work and give public talks on topics of interest.  

The project goals are to provide a satisfactory computational analysis of the liquid stream breakup at a supercritical pressure and to determine the important mixing length scales with real-gas equations of state and phase-equilibrium laws. The amount of gases dissolving into the liquid and the new, substantially higher critical pressure will be determined, establishing when two distinct phases exist. Both liquids and gases will be compressible and have variable density at high pressures. The analysis will give predictions of relevant characteristic time and scales (e.g., diffusion times, frequencies, most unstable wavelengths, and growth rates). The sensible enthalpy, as a function of pressure and temperature; transport properties; surface tension; and energies of vaporization will be determined. Three-dimensional Navier-Stokes solutions, with interface tracking through volume-of-fluid or level-set methods, followed by ?2 vorticity-dynamics analysis will explain the sequence of smaller structures that appear in the breakup cascade. This approach will describe and explain the behavior whether the jet breakup is in a two-phase or supercritical gaseous state; in either case, the smaller structures appear. Atomization, at the Reynolds and Weber numbers of practical interest, will be analyzed and properly viewed as transitional turbulence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The  research goal has been  to explain the breakup  process for a hydrocarbon liquid stream injected into air or oxygen at a pressure above the critical pressure of the hydrocarbon.  The critical pressure provides an upper boundary where liquid and gas phases can be distinguished. Commonly, there is confusion about the critical pressure for a fluid mixture of different materials. The critical pressure for a gas mixture or liquid solution is often well above the critical pressure for any component existing in its pure state, e.g.,  hydrocarbon-liquid fuels flowing together with air or pure oxygen as is commonly found in high-pressure combustors. Thereby, when  two fluid streams of different material are brought together at a pressure well above the critical pressure of each material, the mixture can be sub-critical at that same pressure. A liquid-gas interface can exist with a surface tension and a discontinuity in density. While temperature will be continuous, a heat of vaporization or heat of condensation does exist.

A liquid-gas interface is unstable especially when the two fluids are moving at different velocities. For combustion engines, liquid fuel jets are commonly flowing into oxidizing environments (e.g., air or gaseous oxygen) at a relatively higher velocity. The instability involves rapid deformation of the liquid-gas interface with substantial increase in surface area of the interface. Eventually, this stretching of the interface results in breakup into discrete liquid elements that are no longer connected to the main liquid volume. When the shapes are elongated, they are described as discrete ligaments. When they are closer to oval or spherical shapes, they are described as droplets. Collectively, these discrete elements are described as the spray.  The liquid stream breakup is a cascade process with several distinct steps. The process is commonly named as "atomization", implying smaller elements are being formed from the larger liquid volume.   Under different conditions described by pressure level, density of the two streams, and nondimensional quantities known as Reynolds number and Weber number (which depend on velocity, viscosity, and surface tension), the atomization cascade follows different pathways.

In this work, the domains where two distinct phases will exist were determined and the three-dimensional mechanisms in the cascade process of atomization was determined at those pressures. The following tasks were performed: (1) develop a computational capability, including improved interface tracking, for a three-dimensional, unsteady, two-phase flow with phase-equilibrium and heat and mass exchange at the interface, compressibility and real-fluid properties;  (2) vary  values for Reynolds number, Weber number, ambient gas pressure and temperature, and inflowing-liquid temperature to identify bifurcations in the break-up process;  and (3) use vorticity dynamics (which relates to shear strain and associated rotation of the fluid elements) to explain the physical mechanisms in  small-structure creation and  cause of the breakup.  In all cases, the effects of important parameters were determined: Reynolds number, Weber number, ambient gas pressure, ambient gas temperature, and inflowing-liquid temperature. Pressure and temperatures determine the important ratio of ambient gas density to inflowing-liquid density. Methods for computational cost reduction for solutions are examined.

The mixing process, interface thermodynamics, and early deformation of a cool liquid n-decane jet surrounded by a hotter moving gas initially composed of pure oxygen were analyzed at various ambient pressures and gas velocities. The importance of transcritical mixing effects over time for increasing pressures is shown. Surface-area growth at transcritical conditions is mainly a consequence of gas-like deformations under shear rather than spray formation.

A volume-of-fluid method  is used to solve the low-Mach-number governing equations coupled with a thermodynamic model based on the Soave-Redlich-Kwong equation of state. The mixing process, interface thermodynamics, and early deformation of a cool liquid jet composed of n-decane surrounded by a hotter gas composed of oxygen at 150 bars have been analyzed. Although heat conducts from the hotter gas into the liquid, net condensation can provide the proper local energy balance at high pressures. Then, vaporization and condensation may happen simultaneously at different interface locations. As pressure increases, liquid and gas mixtures become more alike in the vicinity of the interface. Thus, a combination of low surface tension force and gas-like liquid viscosities causes an early growth of surface instabilities. Results indicate some similarity but some differences with high-Weber-number incompressible flows. The role of vortex dynamics on the interface deformation has been  analyzed .

A  UCI graduate student, Jordi Poblador_Ibanez, has been a key participant educated through this research. He just completed his PhD requirements this month and started a position at Argonne National Laboratories.  An undergraduate-student project has been created  and esulted in journal publications; that undergraduate is now a graduate student at Caltech. Findings from this research can flow into the educational materials for courses taught by the PI.  This research might contribute to a future third edition of Professor Sirignano's  entitled "Fluid Dynamics and Transport of Droplets and Sprays".

 

 


Last Modified: 07/06/2022
Modified by: William A Sirignano
